title: 106_s2463
content: The Act titled "National Death Penalty Moratorium Act of 2000" establishes a moratorium on the death penalty. Congress finds that death sentences are disproportionately imposed on the poor and certain racial and ethnic groups, with evidence showing disparities in legal representation and execution rates. Since 1976, African-Americans have accounted for a disproportionate percentage of executions, death row inmates, and victims in death penalty cases. A study in 1994 found that the majority of defendants selected for capital prosecution under the Anti-Drug Abuse Act of 1988 were African-American or Hispanic American. The House Judiciary Subcommittee study in 1994 found that 89% of defendants chosen for capital prosecution under the Anti-Drug Abuse Act of 1988 were African-American or Hispanic American. The General Accounting Office in 1990 reported racial disparities in charging, sentencing, and the death penalty. The Supreme Court has limited death row prisoners' rights to appeal since 1976, increasing the risk of imprisoning and executing innocent individuals. The Supreme Court has restricted death row prisoners' rights to appeal since 1976, leading to an increased risk of imprisoning and executing innocent individuals. Legislation in 1996 further limited Federal court review of death penalty appeals and reduced public funding for legal aid services for death row prisoners. The Federal Government and States are prohibited from carrying out the death penalty until Congress reviews the final findings and recommendations of the National Commission on the Death Penalty. This moratorium will remain in place until legislation is enacted based on the Commission's guidelines and procedures. The National Commission on the Death Penalty is established with 15 members appointed by the President. The Commission includes prosecutors, defense attorneys, and judges. The National Commission on the Death Penalty consists of 15 members appointed by the President, including prosecutors, defense attorneys, judges, and individuals with expertise in relevant matters. The National Commission on the Death Penalty, consisting of 15 members appointed by the President, may include officers or employees of the Federal Government, academia, nonprofit organizations, the religious community, industry, and other interested individuals. The President must ensure a balanced membership with varying opinions on the death penalty. Initial appointments should be made within 30 days of the Act's enactment. The National Commission on the Death Penalty, consisting of 15 members appointed by the President, must have a balanced membership with varying opinions on the death penalty. Members are appointed for the life of the Commission, vacancies are filled in the same manner as the original appointment, and the Commission must hold its first meeting within 30 days of all initial members being appointed. Meetings are held at the call of the Chairperson, with a majority of members constituting a quorum for conducting business. The Commission, once members are appointed, will hold its first meeting. Meetings will be called by the Chairperson, with a majority of members needed for a quorum. The President will designate a member to serve as the Chair. The Commission will establish rules and procedures for its proceedings. The Commission will have duties as outlined in Section 202. The Commission will conduct a study on the administration of the death penalty to ensure it aligns with constitutional principles, including examining racial disparities and adequacy of representation for capital defendants. The Commission will study the administration of the death penalty, focusing on racial disparities, geographic and income-based disproportionality in capital decisions, adequacy of representation for capital defendants, and wrongful convictions leading to death sentences. The Commission will study the administration of the death penalty, focusing on racial disparities, geographic and income-based disproportionality in capital decisions, adequacy of representation for capital defendants, wrongful convictions leading to death sentences, competency of counsel in capital cases, innocence of persons sentenced to death, federal government seeking death penalty in states without it, courts' independent judgment on constitutional claims, and sentencing mentally retarded and juvenile offenders to death. The Commission will study the administration of the death penalty, focusing on racial disparities, geographic and income-based disproportionality in capital decisions, adequacy of representation for capital defendants, wrongful convictions leading to death sentences, competency of counsel in capital cases, innocence of persons sentenced to death, federal government seeking death penalty in states without it, courts' independent judgment on constitutional claims, and sentencing mentally retarded and juvenile offenders to death. The study will also address procedures to ensure access to forensic evidence and modern testing, as well as other laws and procedures to ensure fair and impartial administration of death penalty cases in accordance with the Constitution. The Commission will establish guidelines and procedures to ensure fair and impartial administration of death penalty cases, minimizing the risk of executing innocent persons. The guidelines and procedures for death penalty cases aim to ensure fair and impartial administration, minimize the risk of executing innocent individuals, and prevent racial discrimination. The Commission will submit a preliminary report within one year and a final report within two years of the Act's enactment. The Commission will submit a preliminary report within one year and a final report within two years of the Act's enactment, containing findings, conclusions, and recommendations for legislation and administrative actions. SEC. 203. POWERS OF THE COMMISSION. The Commission has the power to obtain information from Federal and State agencies, use postal services, accept gifts, and conduct hearings as necessary to carry out its provisions. The Commission has the authority to conduct hearings, receive testimony, and issue subpoenas for the production of relevant materials as needed to fulfill its duties. Subpoenas must be signed by the Chairperson and served by designated individuals. The Commission has the authority to issue subpoenas signed by the Chairperson for the production of relevant materials. Subpoenas can be enforced by the district court in cases of non-compliance. The Commission can issue subpoenas to compel testimony or evidence, with failure to comply punishable as contempt. Courts can order persons in custody to testify before the Commission. Witness allowances and fees are governed by section 1821. The Commission can issue subpoenas to compel testimony or evidence, with failure to comply punishable as contempt. Courts can order persons in custody to testify before the Commission. Witness allowances and fees are governed by section 1821 of title 28, United States Code. SEC. 204. COMMISSION PERSONNEL MATTERS. Members of the Commission serve without compensation but are allowed travel expenses. The Chairperson can appoint an executive director and additional staff without following civil service laws, subject to confirmation by the Commission. The Chairperson of the Commission can appoint and terminate an executive director and other necessary personnel without following civil service laws. The compensation for these positions is determined by the Chairperson, with a limit on the pay rate. Federal Government employees can be detailed to the Commission without reimbursement. The Chairperson of the Commission can appoint an executive director and personnel with pay rates capped at level V of the Executive Schedule. Federal Government employees can be detailed to the Commission without reimbursement, and temporary services can be procured at specified rates. The Commission will terminate 90 days after submitting its report. It can spend up to $850,000 for its operations, funded by the Department of Justice.
